HOMEWOOD; BALTIMORE, MD., MARCH 26, 1926.

"HIS MAJESTY"
Peace, perfect peace, has again settled upon the Barn.
After weeks of frantic,hammering and sawing on the part of the
Property Staff; and of nocturnal rehearsals of the equally hard
working cast, the clamor is ceased and the turmoil done. Tonight, the work of all these weeks will reach its consummation
in the opening performance of "His Majesty Bunker Bean" at
the Lyric.
The campus is looking forward to the event expectantly,
for of late years the Barnstormers play has been considered
the leading single event staged by any of the non-athletic activities. And quite rightly so, for the Barnstormers are good.
Plenty of undergraduate talent, interest on the campus, and
the able coaching of Mr. Swindell have succeeded, during the
past few years, in making the Barnstormers a strong organization.
All these factors, coupled with the known ability of this
year's cast, and the happy selection of the play, seem to make
another success assured. So, in common with the rest of the
campus, we are looking forward to seeing -His Majesty" with
a great deal of pleasure, and we wish the Barnstormers all
the luck in the world, which, however, we know they will not
need.

TWENTY-FOUR HOUR SERVICE
Another event which helps to make this evening a really
red letter date is the appearance of the Celebrity Number of
the Black and Blue Jay.
The Jay shares the fate reserved for most campus .periodicals in that it has come to be'considered very much as a matter
of course. Organizations like the Musical Club and Barnstormers have periods of preparation followed by the climax of a
large performance; and, after basking in the pleasant rays of
the lime light, they rest on their laurels until the following
year.
But the Black and Blue Jay can follow no such course.
At the very time an issue comes off the press, the staff members are already hard at work preparing the next. There is
no let up, for its regular appearance is fully expected. During
its few years of existence, the Jay has won a real place on the
campus. The same students who take the magazine as a matter of course would be the first to raise violent complaints if it
were not in their mail boxes at the accustomed time.
We would, then, bestow a great deal of rather belated
credit on the men who make up this year's Black and Blue Jay
staff. They have held up the standards of one of the most popular and best organized of the campus activities.
The culmination of this work is the Celebrity Number.
The difficulties in preparing it have been great, but success has
attended them.
After such an achievement, any other activity would settle
back to enjoy a well-earned rest, but the Managing Editor of
the Jay is already growing gray preparing next month's copy.

Drinking at the University of
Missouri has been officially abolished, with the fraternity men
acting as vigilants. Fraternity
presidents in conference with
school officials adopted a resolution prohibiting drinking at
dances, school functions, and serenades.
The men of the University of
Virginia have an honor agreement
among themselves by which they
are pledged to do no drinking at,
or for six hours before, any university function at which women
are present.

Lacrosse is away with a flurry
this year. All winter the athletic
office has been besieged with many
requests for data concerning the
expense of putting out a lacrosse
team. The movement in the sport
is nation-wide, communications
having come from California and
the south. There are pioneers in
the sport as far south as Alabama.
*

Georgia "Tech" wrote to Father
"Bill" Schmeisser for rules and
directions on how to play the Indian game.
Army, the University's opponent for April 25, has already
worked for some time in preparation for her rather difficult schedule. The high spots of the Army
season will probably be Onondaga, Johns Hopkins and Navy.
The West Point aggregation will
play the Indians before Johns
Hopkins does.
The Rutgers lacrosse squad has
also turned out with five of last
year's first twelve back.
*

*

A recent comparison of figures
" from other college athletic authorities shows the student at this
University to be better off than
the average in regard to fees.
One college has a combined activities and athletic fee of $60 a
year. This is the highest listed.
University of Virginia demands a
fee of $20 for the same privileges
that are here offered. Yale and
Other colleges ask a larger fee
than does Johns Hopkins and in
addition asks another sum to defray the expenses of towel service
and lockets. Notre Dame charges

Jesse Hawley, coach of last
year's famous Dartmouth team,
is of the opinion that the infliction of the penalty will retard the
development of the game and lessen the offensive possibilities from
which a team may choose.
Hawley, whose team depended
largely on the pass as an instrument,of attack, voiced his disappointment at the new ruling. Although the development of the
forward pass has been slow, it has
recently become one of the main
factors of the game. It will now
be relegated to its former use,
that of a last desperate resort.
A five yard penalty will be disregarded by a losing team.
The general opinion is that the
new rule will be a great obstacle
to scientific football. It will lessen interest in the game and cripple one .of its most popular features. Football will tend to revert to the old close defense and
line-backing style.
Not least
among the evils arising under the
new conditions will be the increased interruptions and penalties.

HOMEWOOD; BALTIMORE, MD., MARCH 26, 1926.

"HIS MAJESTY"
Peace, perfect peace, has again settled upon the Barn.
After weeks of frantic,hammering and sawing on the part of the
Property Staff; and of nocturnal rehearsals of the equally hard
working cast, the clamor is ceased and the turmoil done. Tonight, the work of all these weeks will reach its consummation
in the opening performance of "His Majesty Bunker Bean" at
the Lyric.
The campus is looking forward to the event expectantly,
for of late years the Barnstormers play has been considered
the leading single event staged by any of the non-athletic activities. And quite rightly so, for the Barnstormers are good.
Plenty of undergraduate talent, interest on the campus, and
the able coaching of Mr. Swindell have succeeded, during the
past few years, in making the Barnstormers a strong organization.
All these factors, coupled with the known ability of this
year's cast, and the happy selection of the play, seem to make
another success assured. So, in common with the rest of the
campus, we are looking forward to seeing -His Majesty" with
a great deal of pleasure, and we wish the Barnstormers all
the luck in the world, which, however, we know they will not
need.

TWENTY-FOUR HOUR SERVICE
Another event which helps to make this evening a really
red letter date is the appearance of the Celebrity Number of
the Black and Blue Jay.
The Jay shares the fate reserved for most campus .periodicals in that it has come to be'considered very much as a matter
of course. Organizations like the Musical Club and Barnstormers have periods of preparation followed by the climax of a
large performance; and, after basking in the pleasant rays of
the lime light, they rest on their laurels until the following
year.
But the Black and Blue Jay can follow no such course.
At the very time an issue comes off the press, the staff members are already hard at work preparing the next. There is
no let up, for its regular appearance is fully expected. During
its few years of existence, the Jay has won a real place on the
campus. The same students who take the magazine as a matter of course would be the first to raise violent complaints if it
were not in their mail boxes at the accustomed time.
We would, then, bestow a great deal of rather belated
credit on the men who make up this year's Black and Blue Jay
staff. They have held up the standards of one of the most popular and best organized of the campus activities.
The culmination of this work is the Celebrity Number.
The difficulties in preparing it have been great, but success has
attended them.
After such an achievement, any other activity would settle
back to enjoy a well-earned rest, but the Managing Editor of
the Jay is already growing gray preparing next month's copy.

Lacrosse is away with a flurry
this year. All winter the athletic
office has been besieged with many
requests for data concerning the
expense of putting out a lacrosse
team. The movement in the sport
is nation-wide, communications
having come from California and
the south. There are pioneers in
the sport as far south as Alabama.
*

Georgia "Tech" wrote to Father
"Bill" Schmeisser for rules and
directions on how to play the Indian game.

season will probably be Onondaga, Johns Hopkins and Navy.

play the Indians before Johns
Hopkins does.

also turned out with five of last
year's first twelve back.

University to be better off than

that are here offered. Yale and

Jesse Hawley, coach of last
year's famous Dartmouth team,
is of the opinion that the infliction of the penalty will retard the
development of the game and lessen the offensive possibilities from
which a team may choose.
Hawley, whose team depended
largely on the pass as an instrument,of attack, voiced his disappointment at the new ruling. Although the development of the
forward pass has been slow, it has
recently become one of the main
factors of the game. It will now
be relegated to its former use,
that of a last desperate resort.
A five yard penalty will be disregarded by a losing team.
The general opinion is that the
new rule will be a great obstacle
to scientific football. It will lessen interest in the game and cripple one .of its most popular features. Football will tend to revert to the old close defense and
line-backing style.
Not least
among the evils arising under the
new conditions will be the increased interruptions and penalties.
